name: Methyl 3-nitrobenzoate
Reason: To predict the melting point of methyl 3-nitrobenzoate, we need to consider the functional groups within the molecule and their effect on intermolecular forces. The base structure here is benzene, which has a melting point of 5.5°C. Adding a methyl ester group typically raises the melting point because it increases molecular weight and enhances van der Waals forces; the effect could be estimated at around +40°C. The nitro group is a strong electron-withdrawing group and due to its polarity, can form strong intermolecular dipoles, which would significantly increase the melting point because it would contribute to the rigidity of the molecular structure. We might estimate the effect of a nitro group to be around +60°C. Summing up these modifications to the base benzene value gives us the predicted melting point.

name: Methyl 3-nitrobenzoate
Reason: To predict the melting point of methyl 3-nitrobenzoate, the influence of its functional groups on intermolecular forces needs to be considered. Starting from the base structure of benzene, with a melting point of 5.5°C, we analyze the contributions of the functional groups. The methyl ester (–COOCH3) group usually increases the melting point by introducing additional van der Waals forces due to a higher molecular weight and offers the possibility of limited hydrogen bonding via the oxygen atom; this could be estimated at around +30°C. The nitro (–NO2) group strongly affects the melting point due to its electron-withdrawing nature and polarity, which can lead to enhanced dipole-dipole interactions and possible hydrogen bonding with adjacent molecules; this effect can be substantial and may increase the melting point by approximately +40°C. The cumulative effect of these groups is added to the base value of benzene to predict the melting point of the molecule.
